subject: Re: novice QA
msgSnippet: Jason, Thanks for your advice! The printstream is a good idea, I think I will explore with that. ... allow the ... method ... printstream ... contains ...
messageBody:
Jason,

Thanks for your advice! The printstream is a good idea, I think I
will explore with that.

--- In junit@y..., "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@t...> wrote:
> A couple of brute force ideas...
>
> Is there any reason not to open up the vector to the client and
allow the
> client to decide what to do with it? You can still have the print
method
> that will format the contents of the vector for you.
>
> If you don't want to open up the vector, how about passing in a
printstream
> to the print method? That way you could test that the stream
contains
> everything you expect it to have.
>
> FYI: There is overhead in Vector that probably isn't needed in your
class --
> you should be using a List (i.e. ArrayList).
>
> -Jason
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: the_shark_tank@y... [mailto:the_shark_tank@y...]
> > Sent: Monday, August 06, 2001 3:45 PM
> > To: junit@y...
> > Subject: [junit] novice QA
> >
> >
> > Hello All!
> >
> > I am invading your group as a mere QA intern. . . I am
> > supposed to
> > implement junit tests on code that I have just written.
> > However, what
> > I have learned in school does not seem to apply here! We
learned
> > that if the method is an "add" method, give it two numbers,
> > and "assert" that the corrent addition is performed, and
> > so on. . .
> > well, I have no clue what to assert!
> >
> > Quick rundown of what I am testing:
> >
> > Basically, my code is using the Reflection class to check all
the
> > members of a class for a certain type of compatibility.
> > Most methods
> > add errors to an error vector, and then there is a simple
print
> > function to print out the vector... How on earth do I test
this
> > class??
> >
> > Thanks for any help in advance!!
> >
> > Yours truly,
> > The Shark
> >
> >
